qas.question: What opinions do Croatian Nationalists have on the language issue?

answers.text: they speak an entirely separate language from Serbs and Bosnians

qas.question: Which language did Ljudevit Gaj and Vuk Karadzic prefer?
Where is the Neostokavian-Ijekavian language predominantely spoken?
How do Serbian nationalists feel about the Croatians using their language?
What do Bosnians have conflicting views on?
Who claims that the Stokavian dialect has appropriated the Bosnian language?

plausible_answers.text: any divergence in the language is artificial

qas.question: What do Cakavian Croats claim about language divergence?

plausible_answers.text: Croats have "taken" or "stolen" their language from the Serbs

qas.question: What do Bosnians claim in extreme formulations about language?

plausible_answers.text: they speak an entirely separate language from Serbs and Bosnians

qas.question: What is one thing Neostokavian nationalists claim about Serbs and Bosnians?

context: Nationalists have conflicting views about <b4_0>the language(s)<b4_0/>. The nationalists among the Croats conflictingly claim either that <a0_0><b8_0>they speak an entirely separate language from Serbs and Bosnians<b8_0/><a0_0/> or that these two peoples have, due to the longer lexicographic tradition among Croats, somehow "borrowed" their standard languages from them.[citation needed] <b5_0>Bosniak nationalists<b5_0/> claim that both Croats and Serbs have "appropriated" the Bosnian language, since Ljudevit Gaj and Vuk Karadžić preferred the <a1_0>Neoštokavian-Ijekavian<a1_0/> dialect, widely spoken in <a2_0>Bosnia and Herzegovina<a2_0/>, as the basis for language standardization, whereas the nationalists among the Serbs claim either that <b6_0>any divergence in the language is artificial<b6_0/>, or claim that the Štokavian dialect is theirs and the Čakavian Croats'— in more extreme formulations <a3_0><b7_0>Croats have "taken" or "stolen" their language<a3_0/> from the Serbs<b7_0/>.[citation needed]
